Introduction

(Published on August 3, 2025)

In this article, I will walk through the LEMP Configuration.

<br>

LEMP VPS deployment

<div class="separator"></div> In this article, we will walk through the steps of configure a web application using vultr server and domain with ssl from cloudflare.

<center> <i> flow web application</i> </center>

Server (Vultr)
â”œâ”€â”€ Web Server
â”œâ”€â”€ Database MySQL
â”œâ”€â”€ Firewall
â”œâ”€â”€ Php
â”œâ”€â”€ Composer
â”œâ”€â”€ SSH
â”œâ”€â”€ SSL
â””â”€â”€ Git 


Domain (Cloudflare)
â”œâ”€â”€ buy domain
â””â”€â”€ set dns

<br><br>

Server Vultr Configuration

<div class="separator"></div>

Step intro - Rent Share CPU Server in Vultr

<center> <i> Basic Configuration Server only on 1 server</i> </center>

<div class="credentials-box"> <div class="hierarchy-list">

Step 1 â€” Installing Web Server

sudo apt install nginx -y
sudo systemctl start nginx
sudo systemctl enable nginx

Step 2 â€” Installing MySQL

sudo apt install mysql-server -y
sudo mysql_secure_installation

CREATE DATABASE your_database_name;
CREATE USER 'your_username'@'localhost' IDENTIFIED BY 'your_password';
GRANT ALL PRIVILEGES ON your_database_name.* TO 'your_username'@'localhost';
FLUSH PRIVILEGES;
EXIT;

Database Credentials

ðŸ”‘ DB root user (full access)

  • Username: root
  • Password: abc123 (change this in production!)

ðŸ”„ DB normal user (project access)

  • Username: adminProject

  • Password: abc123 (use unique passwords!)

    </div>

</div>

Step 3 â€” Installing Php

sudo apt install php8.3-fpm php8.3-mysql php8.3-cli php8.3-xml php8.3-mbstring php8.3-curl php8.3-zip
sudo systemctl start php8.3-fpm
sudo systemctl enable php8.3-fpm

Step 4 â€” Installing Composer

php -r "copy('https://getcomposer.org/installer', 'composer-setup.php');"
sudo php composer-setup.php --install-dir=/usr/local/bin --filename=composer
php -r "unlink('composer-setup.php');"

Step 5 â€” Generate ssh key

ssh-keygen -t rsa -b 4096
cat ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub

Step 6 â€” Create Laravel Project

cd /var/www/
composer create-project --prefer-dist laravel/laravel project
cp .env.example .env
nano .env


APP_URL=http://project.com

DB_CONNECTION=mysql
DB_HOST=127.0.0.1
DB_PORT=3306
DB_DATABASE=project
DB_USERNAME=adminProject
DB_PASSWORD=xxxxxx

Step 7 â€” Set permission laravel file

php artisan key:generate
sudo chown -R www-data:www-data /var/www/project/storage /var/www/project/bootstrap/cache
sudo chmod -R 775 /var/www/project/storage /var/www/project/bootstrap/cache
php artisan migrate

Step 8 â€” Installing Git

git init
git config --global user.name "momotaro"
git config --global user.email momo@gmail.com
git branch -M main
git commit -m "first commit"
git remote add origin git@github.com:momo/project.git
git branch -m master main
git add .
git commit -m "Initial commit"
git push -u origin main
git push origin main

Step 9 â€” Allowing firewall port (http and https)

 sudo ufw allow http
 sudo ufw allow https
 sudo ufw reload

Step 10 â€” Configuring domain name in Web Service

cd /etc/nginx/sites-available/
sudo unlink /etc/nginx/sites-enabled/default

nano project.conf


#==============
# project.conf
#=============

#=========
#normal config no ssl cloudflare
#=========
server {
    server_name project.com www.project.com;

    root /var/www/project/public;
    index index.php index.html;

    location / {
        try_files $uri $uri/ /index.php?$query_string;
    }

    location ~ \.php$ {
        include snippets/fastcgi-php.conf;
        fastcgi_pass unix:/run/php/php8.3-fpm.sock;
    }

    location ~ /\.ht {
        deny all;
    }
}

#=============
# configure with ssl cloudflare
#=============
# Redirect HTTP to HTTPS (Cloudflare-friendly)
server {
    listen 80;
    listen [::]:80;
    server_name project.com www.project.com;
    return 301 https://project.com$request_uri;
}

# Main HTTPS server
server {
    listen 443 ssl http2;
    listen [::]:443 ssl http2;
    server_name project.com www.project.com;

    # SSL (Use Cloudflare Origin Certificate)
    ssl_certificate     /etc/cloudflare/project.com.pem;
    ssl_certificate_key /etc/cloudflare/project.com.key;
    
    # Basic SSL settings (safe defaults)
    ssl_protocols TLSv1.2 TLSv1.3;
    ssl_prefer_server_ciphers on;
    ssl_session_timeout 1d;
    ssl_session_cache shared:SSL:10m;

    # Website root
    root /var/www/project/public;
    index index.php index.html;

    # Handle requests
    location / {
        try_files $uri $uri/ /index.php?$query_string;
    }

    # PHP-FPM config
    location ~ \.php$ {
        include snippets/fastcgi-php.conf;
        fastcgi_pass unix:/run/php/php8.3-fpm.sock;
    }

    # Security: Block hidden files
    location ~ /\.ht {
        deny all;
    }
}

sudo ln -s /etc/nginx/sites-available/project.conf /etc/nginx/sites-enabled/
sudo nano  /etc/cloudflare/project.com.pem
sudo nano  /etc/cloudflare/project.com.key
sudo nginx -t
sudo systemctl reload nginx

Step 11 â€” Request SSL free version (optional)

sudo apt install certbot python3-certbot-nginx
sudo certbot --nginx -d project.com -d www.project.com --register-unsafely-without-email --agree-tos
sudo certbot renew --dry-run

##=== confirm a cronjob or systemd===##
systemctl list-timers | grep certbot


# Stop any running Certbot services
sudo systemctl stop certbot.timer
sudo systemctl disable certbot.timer

# Remove Certbot packages
sudo apt remove --purge certbot python3-certbot-nginx

# Remove any remaining configuration files
sudo rm -rf /etc/letsencrypt/
sudo rm -rf /var/log/letsencrypt/

# Clean up unused dependencies
sudo apt autoremove

Domain Cloudflare

SSL Cloudflare

Conclusion

by doing this basic configuration on real hands on you can learned the way project deploy in real case. Also you will more understand on what the item checking need to be configure in order to run your web app.

item.description: Mysql Replication on how make backup database server
item.content:encoded:
Introduction to MySQL Replication (Master-Slave)

have the basic knowledge replication mysql by own simulation in virtualbox

<!-- </div> -->

<br>

Introduction

<div class="separator"></div> In this article, we will walk through the steps of creating a simple database replication using virtualbox simulation.

Two Server linux
â”œâ”€â”€ Database Master
â””â”€â”€ Database Slave

Internet Connection for download
â”œâ”€â”€

<br><br>

Step 1: Server Configuration

<div class="separator"></div>

Step 1.1 â€” Install two Ubuntu OS on Virtualbox

<div class="separator"></div> you can setup as below:

<center> <i> Master Slave Diagram Configuration.</i> </center>

<div class="credentials-box"> <div class="hierarchy-list">

Database Credentials

ðŸ”‘ DB Master

  • Username: ubuntu1
  • Password: abc123 (change this in production!)

ðŸ”„ DB Slave (Replica)

  • Username: ubuntu2

  • Password: abc123 (use unique passwords!)

    </div>

</div>

Step 2: MySQL

Step 2.1 â€” Installing MySQL (Master & Slave Server)

# update server package
sudo apt update
# install mysql package
sudo apt install mysql-server
# start the mysql service
sudo systemctl start mysql.service

Step 2.2 â€” Configure MySQL User (Master & Slave Server)

# Command
$ sudo mysql  //enter into mysql

# IN MYSQL Configure User access by password
mysql> ALTER USER 'root'@'localhost' IDENTIFIED WITH mysql_native_password BY 'password';  //update access root mysql
mysql> exit //exit

# Re-enter MYSQL User mysql by password
$ mysql -u root -p  //enter into mysql

# by default mysql user use auth_socket:
# for revert change the access as default run command in mysql as below:
mysql> ALTER USER 'root'@'localhost' IDENTIFIED WITH auth_socket;

Step 2.3 â€” Configure MySQL Source

// Command
$ sudo nano /etc/mysql/mysql.conf.d/mysqld.cnf  //change the mysql config

//In mysqld.cnf change as below:
bind-address = 0.0.0.0 //source_server_ip
server-id = 1 // for server master, then set 2 if Slave
log_bin = /var/log/mysql/mysql-bin.log
# binlog_do_db = include_database_name //open if want to replicate db
# binlog_ignore_db = db_to_ignore // /open if remove replicate db
relay-log = /var/log/mysql/mysql-relay-bin.log //open for slave only

Ctr+x then y.

//Restart MYSQL
$ sudo systemctl restart mysql

Step 2.4 â€” Configure MySQL Master

# Command
$ mysql -u root -p  //enter into mysql

# IN MYSQL Configure Replica User access by password
mysql> CREATE USER 'replica'@'*' IDENTIFIED WITH mysql_native_password BY 'Replica'; //create access replica mysql
mysql> GRANT REPLICATION SLAVE ON *.* TO 'replica'@'192.168.56.102';
mysql> FLUSH PRIVILEGES;
mysql> exit //exit

# Re-enter MYSQL User mysql by password
$ mysql -u replica -p  //enter into mysql to test

mysql> SHOW MASTER STATUS;

Step 2.4 â€” Configure MySQL Slave

# Command
$ mysql -u root -p  //enter into mysql

# IN MYSQL Configure Replica Source
mysql> CHANGE REPLICATION SOURCE TO
mysql> SOURCE_HOST='192.168.1.1',
mysql> SOURCE_USER='replica',
mysql> SOURCE_PASSWORD='Replica',
mysql> SOURCE_LOG_FILE='mysql-bin.000001',
mysql> SOURCE_LOG_POS=899;
mysql> exit //exit

// Start Replica in slave
mysql> START REPLICA;
mysql> SHOW REPLICA STATUS\G;

Step 3.1 â€” Test write the recod data in Master & show in Slave

================
//MASTER DB
================
# Command
$ mysql -u root -p  //enter into mysql

mysql> create database test;
mysql> show databases;

================
//SLAVE DB
================
# Command
$ mysql -u root -p  //enter into mysql

mysql> show databases;
mysql> SHOW REPLICA STATUS\G;

Conclusion

Master-slave replication only single directional write. Only master database can write while slave only can read. It is important for us alert and grab this concept precisely.Also if you want replicate the master that already have data and db,make sure you copy the db and dump into replica db first.

you can use method to copy db as below:

SCP METHOD:
â”œâ”€â”€ scp "source" "destination" <br />
â””â”€â”€ scp db.sql sammy@replica_server_ip:/tmp/

MYSQL DUMP METHOD:
â”œâ”€â”€ mysqldump -u "username" -p "database" "table" > "destination_file.sql" <br />
â””â”€â”€  mysqldump -u test -p db_master > "home/user1.sql"

References

Reference web link:

  1. Install Mysql on Ubuntu 20.04 <a target="_blank" href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-install-mysql-on-ubuntu-20-04">(link)</a>
  2. Setup Mysql Replication <a target="_blank" href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-set-up-replication-in-mysql">(link)</a>
